review_title: Hiring processes iffy, no attempts to get rid of chaff
pros: Job security is good. The people I work with are good (mostly). The job itself is enjoyable. Potential to earn more than posted salary with overtime. Pay is always on time. Time off is the golden handcuffs and you get quite a lot of time off. Therefore work life balance is considered good. It also makes it hard to leave the job though.
cons: Management could be better. No attempt to get rid of useless people. They move the problem on to a different team. Hiring process flawed, new officers move on when they realise how much walking is involved. Took 15yrs for our department to get a pay rise. Things tend to move… s l o w l y… here. No real opportunity to progress in the department. Would be nice to have actual company benefits like free use of the gym, discounted food/ drink from cafes. Additionally, access to study courses and career development opportunities for reduced fee. Provide a comfortable relaxation break room/ space.

review_title: Post Covid the environment is growing quite toxic, staff and student burnt out is widespread
pros: A certain level of hybrid working where possible is mainstream now. Flexible working hours is usually well honoured. If something is for the betterment of an aspect of ED&I, you can usually be granted a (very tight) budget. Some of the gardens and building architecture can be very beautiful. When I first joined it was a genuinely nice, joyful and supportive place to work which makes it even more of a shame how fundamentally different it is now.
cons: The salaries have not kept in line with the cost of living in Bristol. The uni is very much a business and therefore quality for teaching provision is cut at every corner possible. This also is leading to insane student numbers. They want the education to be mass produced and have no concerns regarding the student experience on that front. As a business their model is have a shiny superficial face for student tours but one scratch below the surface and the buildings are in poor and very outdated states. People of poorer character are often the ones to be rewarded with promotions, they want people who toe the line and will be the hench men of the powers that be. Leads to a very strong culture of mid level management and above listening to reply, never to understand. Progression within your role is about as painful as it can be. I have seen colleagues have to apply for the job they are already doing three times and get rejected. They have had to do this because progression within your own job is essentially impossible. With that in mind, the uni is very keen on maintaining its Ivory Tower ways and very well experienced academics get passed over for jobs they are already doing in favour of people with PhDs but little to no experience. The academics without PhDs are facing a future of very stunted progression regardless of excelling at their jobs because they don't have a title. The student recruitment process is still resulting in the scale always tipping heavily towards white students from very privileged backgrounds. The students not in this category are the minority and are well aware of that fact and will report back about how obvious it is and how uncomfortable being an outsider is. Due to how elitist the senior management is with staff progression, it is unsurprising the attainment of students still appears very classist. I have never seen a maternity cover hire once in my years at UoB. When someone goes on matleave, the management just expect you to pick up everything without any help. Its extraordinary considering how much they want Athena Swan prizes. The NSS results matter far more than anything else, for better or worse. The work culture is extremely toxic now and most of my coworkers and I are very stressed out, genuinely quite hurt and burnt out.

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Bristol, England
pros: City centre location with beautiful gardens at the top of St. Michael's Hill
cons: The Biomedical Sciences Building is literally falling apart and the university will not address it. A large sum of money was spent refurbishing the 'social space' and cafeteria on the ground floor to attract prospective students but other areas (where staff actually work) are a complete mess. On two occasions I have found ceiling panels that have crumbled to the floor due to water leaks. The estates department will clear away debris but do not seem to deal with the cause of the problem. Many research staff are overwhelmed with the number of students assigned to them for lab placements. We are expected to accept up to three students at a time and still maintain our research output. There is no official recognition for our contribution to this teaching, which makes it feel like a thoroughly thankless task.

pros: some unit directors and senior tutors are very supportive and listen to students and help them resolve problems
cons:
- Most of the heads and people in charge view student's feedback and support request as the student's inability to coop with the challenges they set, which is not true. They constantly change how units are run and assessed and never actually put themselves in the shoe of the student to anticipate the their 'experiments' results on them. 
- They never share any information or statistics with their students even if we ask for class averages to assess how pre-covid cohorts have been advantaged over us. 
- Many of my coursemates have encountered medical problems during covid and most of their doctors told them that stress was the reason, yet, the department did not bother to collaborate or support their students nor believe their suffering (they only think students are weak to go through the challenges of Aerospace).

review_title: A mixture of disheartening and positive
pros: It's a lovely place to live (cheap compared to London, expensive compared to some other places). The university has some excellent research support infrastructure (the RED office has got to be one of the best of its kind in the UK, the Centre for Public Engagement and the Press Offices too are excellent, full of skilled people but a bit underfunded).
cons: As with a lot of the sector, the damage casualisation does to careers and to student experiences are a problem. The effects of diabolical management practices at Faculty level seem to reverberate for years and, in general, those in decision-making positions are often observed to be either disturbingly capricious or overly cautious. The 'silo effect; at Bristol is most pronounced and seems very hard to overcome indeed. The institution also has a long way to go in terms of gender equality and ethnic diversity but these are widely acknowledged with a sense of hopelessness, in a reminiscent of some other Russell Group universities. The university is creeping toward addressing other diversity issues with Stonewall accreditation being considered. On these fronts it lags behind UWE quite significantly.

pros: Enjoyment of a PhD depends mostly on the individual and is hard to tell whether it is right fo you before you start, so my experience will differ wildly to yours. That being said, Bristol has a lot going for it as a place to attempt a PhD: The city itself is lovely with lots going on but is still small enough to walk everywhere. The university has a supportive and relaxed feel, perfect for coping with the stresses of research life.
cons: Again, your experience of your PhD will be quite personal. I found very few aspects which I did not like, and the ones I encountered were quite minor. For example, one can voluntarily tutor undergraduates or grade exams for some extra money and experience teaching. These seem to be paid well until you realise you are not allocated nearly as much time as you will spend actually completeing the work. All such work was voluntary in my experience, so I don't weight it heavily at all.

review_title: Benefits are amazing - business is antiquated
pros:
- annual leave
- flexible working, a proper understanding of having caring commitments outside work and how unpredictable they can be
- in some areas you are really working with ground breaking knowledge, as a non-academic, I feel I can make a difference to some really exciting research and development.
- School of Physics are supportive, inclusive and progressive.
cons:
- career development for non- academics is limited
- top heavy management structure, strongly focused on what they can get for the minimum
- short sighted strategy on almost every level, it is left to lower grades on the coal face to deliver for the staff and students they work with.
- parking/transpart, the city centre campus is great if you walk but if not, it can be really tough.

job_title: Teaching Support Assistant in Bristol, England

--Really bad IT service (mainly due to the way it is organized),  which makes it very hard to deliver high quality teaching. For example the industrial software used for teaching may be broken after major update on the operating systems and no one notice and fixed them until term starts,

review_title: An amazing institution to work for, very passionate for the success of the University of Bristol
pros: Great structures are in place to ensure that staff are well looked after and supported.  Full of lovely people who strive to make the University not only a great place to work but also give students a fantastic experience.  Development opportunities are great, the University offers a great wide range of courses that you can attend whilst working there from IT courses to Women Self-defence classes.
cons: No cons at all.

review_title: Working as a  researcher at Bristol Uni
pros: If you have a good boss and a smoothly going project, you will have a very flexible working life. Normally there are chances to attend one international conference and one national conference per year, and you can always extend your travel with your annual holiday.
cons: The quality of your research life or even personal life while working in academia really depends a lot on your boss's working style (or even personality). Bristol is a big university with a lot of rules/guidance/procedures, which means that all the training/risk assessment always take lone time (normally one month) when you are a fresher.

pros: Pay was in line with other unis. Positive working environment usually but not always. Usual benefits from working at a university such as flexible hours. Amazing city!
cons: Leadership suffered from the pitfalls that almost all unis do - scientists are not managers! Often treated poorly by senior staff who have a very hierarchal view of the institution. Certain aspects of the university were an absolute shambles usually down to poor communication, organisation and attitude. Again, as is normal for university research positions, the scope for career progression is limited with very few positions above postdoctoral roles.

pros: Got an opportunity to gain hands-on experience at manufacturing composite structures using curing ovens and autoclaves. The staff at ACCIS labs was highly skilled and experienced. The lab technicians provided assistance and guidance at all times to help the students attain the desired level of experience and prevent any scope of mistakes. Also, working in the ACCIS department had been a wonderful experience since one can share ideas and attain assistance from current PhD students and senior lecturers.
cons: The only downside was that the lab inductions were conducted in the second week of the internship that led to a slight change in my internship plan.

pros: Great people, good conditions, flexible working, good leave and pension (even now).  Working in Clifton is a bonus as there are good shops, cafés and restaurants on the doorstep although you have to watch your spending.
cons: Resources are being reduced but the work not so resource is stretched in many areas.  Many staff are stressed and unhappy but do not leave because the conditions are good.

pros:
If you are looking to be a hall tutor while studying at Bristol, I would highly recommend it. Hall tutorship offer subsidised accommodation (when I was there I believe it was 30% of standard accommodations fees, about £250 or so every term, which is every three and a half months). 

You will develop leadership skills. Trying to find that balance with your tutees respecting you while still being someone they could confide int. Great support from other tutors and Warden in helping you understand how to deal with many situations. They will offer your training before the academic year starts on everything you need from first aid, University policies, how deal with students in certain situations, fire safety, etc.

The room you will get will be very large (larger than standard) and you will enjoy free internet as well.
cons:
- A great deal of drama within the hall among the tutors. Be prepared for allot of politics. Most tutors are easy going, nice people, and will be good and lasting friends. However, as with most situations, there will be one or two tutors (usually senior tutors) who will go on power trips and thing they are far more important than what is reality.
-You will have duties in the evenings and on weekends. The duty itself is not so bad, except that you can not leave your hall at all (not even to get some lunch). This is especially annoying if you get a Saturday morning or evening shift (regardless of when you get your duty, your Saturday or Sunday free time will limit what you can do).
-Your tutees will eventually get a chip on their shoulder (this happens during the 2nd term for most) and will be louder and a bit more "daring" in what they do.

Important - every hall will have different set of rules. The Wardens are diverse. Some Wardens are more traditional. Believe it or not they are the more liberal ones because they have more experience and do not overreact to every little thing. Every Warden is different and will have different set of rules

review_title: A pleasure and an honour to be a student at this university.
pros: With the ridiculous numbers of places to work and the view from some of them it almost makes the hills tolerable! It's pretty incredible to show people the uni with the architecture of the buildings we have, Wills will never lose the wow factor and its utter charm no mater how many times you use it as a meet up point. With staff being friendly and helpful it's nice not to be spoken down to or be patronised after reels of questions that are asked to lecturers or any staff member really. To have been so accommodating on my arrival to the university, it almost makes me feel it is my duty to provide that experience to any first year I come across in the following years. I'm an international ambassador and with that I have realised the lengths the university goes to, to ensure everyone is accommodated in there needs and how happy to help everyone is. Plus if you really think about it, i'm taking time out to do this for free so that's got to speak for itself...
cons: For me it is a rather painful journey home with bristol's out of the way location so that is definitely a draw back. I suppose I wish there was  integration between different years, that did not involve heavily drinking or a night club. socials only seem to take the form of a bar crawl and that never is a social situation really because people stick to who they know, and probably won't remember anyone new with the level of intoxication they reach. I also would have liked the student union to offer things like pool and snooker, a social place for one to actually go because it's such a beautiful building inside, more people should have reason to use it.

review_title: Intensely bureaucratic university which stifles creativity and blames its staff for its inefficiencies
pros: Great staff members on the academic side. A nice campus in a beautiful city. I have to write 20 words minimum here, but I've run out of nice things to say.
cons:
I've worked at many universities and this is by far the worst experience I've had. The bureaucracy is labyrinthine and brutally inefficient. While your colleagues might be nice, the decision-makers and administrators have zero interest in the human realities of the job and want to micromanage your every move. The administrators and managers  have truly mastered the art of buck-passing while constantly making you feel like you're on trial.

When the average employee at Bristol mentions work on Facebook, it's because they're upset or angry.

Any payroll issues you have will be deemed your fault (I ended up landed with a tax bill for £400 due to Bristol's errors (confirmed by HMRC), but told to suck it up).

You will be confronted with endless and ridiculous forms (e.g. expenses claims can only be submitted through ancient software that runs ONLY on internet explorer and requires you to know dozens of codes and acronyms that will not be provided to you).

Expenses claims – including payment of research assistants – takes an inordinate amount of time to be completed, which is embarrassing at the professional level and also unacceptable to the researchers.

If you have any other choice of workplace, go somewhere else before this place kills your passion.

pros: Supportive colleagues at a non-mangerial level.  Very engaged at student and PGR level.
cons: The culture is one of blame and unhealthy level of competition - this is something that comes right from the top.   Only small pockets of collegiate culture.  Overly bureaucratic processes.

pros:

best team to be a part of!

review_title: A good start to a career
pros:
Flexible working hours, great for full-time students
Plenty of work and career related training available through the career services
cons: The claim system was outdated and did not work properly. Unable to claim your work online, instead a printed claim forms where still in use in 2017!

pros: Great office environment, work space and nice people. I worked very hard and that was recognised so gradually was given more responsibilities over time.
cons: Poor salary for apprentice level (under min-wage). Very hierarchical company with traditional values and also not much training support. I poured a lot of coffees and did a lot of photocopying.

review_title: A great prestigious Russell group university - Research Assistant
pros: Excellent research environment, facilities, people. The composite centre is one of the very best in the world. Bristol Uni is surrounded by aerospace major players such as Agusta-Westland, Airbus, RollsRoyce, MBDA, GKN, etc... The university own the national composite centre the largest of its kind in Europe. Excellent location and the city is great to live in.
cons: Bristol is more expensive than other UK cities especially rent...

review_title: great, as long as you have a permanent contract
pros: Great city, interesting colleagues, inspiring students, flexible work environment
cons: MASSIVE increase in casualisation. If you are on Pathway 2 or 3, forget ever having a permanent contract. Exploitation of graduate students to teach the huge increase in undergraduate numbers. Unsupportive management culture, an HR team that seem to have taken it on themselves to block progression and promotion for most staff.

review_title: Like being in a battery farm
pros: It used to be a good place to work. Not any more.
cons: So-called 'new ways of working' are a money saving exercise that crams employees into open plan offices with a bizarre form of hot-desking.  Noisy, stressful, pressured and management just keep moving the desks and cramming more people in without the slightest concern about the impact on staff.  If you value your mental health do not work for UoB at Great George St.

review_title: Great city, reasonable employer in central location, no parking, limited career progression opportunities
pros: Great City, University centrally located (Except for Vets), good pension, reasonable pay, people like to stay on here. Okay relocation packages.
cons: Excessive use of contracts, needs further careers support for contract workers and less management change schemes! Statuatory minimum redundancy.  At certain grades only external candidates are genuinely considered except for a few very lucky exceptions. Housing expensive and mixed quality.

review_title: Fun place to work, but the way things are run centrally will drive you insane.
pros: It's fun and the people are lovely. Good benefits and very flexible.
cons: Many things are run centrally in the university. However, the system is very very poor and the people running the things can be extremely incompetent, you'll be surprised!

review_title: Very nice staff but training has been hard to get.

cons: I have had to learn on the job with little or no training.

review_title: Life sciences building, pretty but frustrating
pros: The building looks great. When I arrived I noticed how relaxed the atmosphere was and how little stress I could see on people's faces.
cons: The usual university beaurocracy meant I didn't get registered onto the ordering system for a few months, laptop didn't arrive until almost 3 months.

pros: Great admin team at the university meaning that it didn't take long for stuff to get done. Really enjoyed my time there. It was rewarding as I could see that the work I was doing was having a real effect on the day to day there. Top stuff.
cons: No real cons, the university were very accommodating throughout my employment. More holiday time would be appreciated.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Assistant in Bristol, England

Many opportunities for undergraduate and post graduate students to improve their knowledge, social skills through societies, teaching tutorial and lab classes. The start salary for research staff is good.
cons: The opportunities for senior positions for research staffs or for whom want to become lecturers are limited.

You would earn much more elsewhere.
